etymologies: Old English scyttan ‘put (a bolt) in position to hold fast’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch schutten ‘shut up, obstruct’, also to shoot

definitions: move (something) into position so as to block an opening; close
shortDefinitions: move something into position so as to block opening

definitions: move or be able to be moved so as to block an opening
shortDefinitions: move or be able to be moved so as to block opening

definitions: block an opening into (something) by moving something into position

examples.text: he shut the box and locked it
he was opening and shutting his mouth

shortDefinitions: block opening into something by moving something into position

examples.text: they ought to shut the path up to that terrible cliff

definitions: fold or bring together the sides of (something) so as to close it
shortDefinitions: fold or bring together sides of something so as to close it

definitions: keep in a place by closing something such as a door

examples.text: it was his own dog which he had accidentally shut outside

shortDefinitions: keep in place by closing something such as door

definitions: make (something) unavailable for business or service, either permanently or until due to be open again

examples.text: we shut the shop for lunch

shortDefinitions: make unavailable for business or service

definitions: become unavailable for business or service, either permanently or until due to be open again

examples.text: the accident and emergency departments will shut

shortDefinitions: become unavailable for business or service
